fullText:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/hadestown-review-a-musical-heats-up-broadway-11555547401

ShareResizeAmber Gray and the Broadway cast of ‘Hadestown’ Matthew MurphyNew York

Does the Broadway musical have a future? Only if a new generation of artists walks away from the old-hit-movie-into-stale-new-stage-show model and starts creating musicals that are conceptually more ambitious. “The Band’s Visit” and “Be More Chill,” which also broke free from the twin strangleholds of by-the-numbers pop-rock and synthetic Disneypop, both filled the bill in their very different ways. So, too, does Anaïs Mitchell’s “Hadestown,” which has transferred to Broadway after highly acclaimed runs at New York Theatre Workshop and London’s Royal National Theatre. “Hadestown” isn’t perfect, but it’s so fresh that you’ll gladly look past its forgivable flaws and savor the kaleidoscopic stylistic variety of Ms. Mitchell’s score.
dtliExcerpt: The result is a show that sounds like no other musical on or off Broadway, one whose score has the craggy authenticity of American folk music at its most uncompromising.
bwwExcerpt: While the stage version of "Hadestown" is longer and considerably more elaborate than the 2010 concept album, it still bears the mark of its origins, and therein lies its chief flaw. Ms. Mitchell's songs are beautiful but undramatic-the score runs mainly to slow and medium tempos-which means that th...
showScoreExcerpt: The result is a show that sounds like no other musical on or off Broadway, one whose score has the craggy authenticity of American folk music at its most uncompromising.

keyPhrases.quote: Hadestown isn't perfect, but it's so fresh that you'll gladly look past its forgivable flaws and savor the kaleidoscopic stylistic variety.

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 4 models agree: Positive | Claude: Clear positive recommendation with enthusiastic praise for the show's freshness and originality. The critic acknowledges minor flaws but frames them as 'forgivable' and emphasizes the show's unique qualities and 'craggy authenticity.' | GPT-4o: The review praises 'Hadestown' for its freshness and uniqueness, encouraging audiences to overlook minor flaws. The tone is enthusiastic, highlighting the show's ambitious and distinctive qualities. | Gemini: The review acknowledges flaws but ultimately recommends the show due to its freshness and unique score. The critic is willing to overlook imperfections, indicating a positive overall experience. | Kimi: The critic praises the show's conceptual ambition and unique folk-influenced score, calling it 'fresh' and unlike any other musical on Broadway, while acknowledging imperfections but urging audiences to see it anyway.
